text: regreSSHion: Remote unauthenticated code execution in OpenSSH server. Race condition in signal handler allows RCE on glibc-based Linux. Affects OpenSSH 8.5p1 through 9.7p1.
OpenSSH ssh-agent remote code execution via PKCS#11 provider. Forwarded agent socket can be exploited for arbitrary code execution on the client.
PwnKit: Local privilege escalation in polkit pkexec. Memory corruption in command-line argument handling allows any unprivileged user to gain root.
Sudo privilege escalation via sudoedit. Arbitrary file write by exploiting user-provided environment variables in sudoedit.
Baron Samedit: Heap-based buffer overflow in sudo. Allows any local user to gain root privileges without authentication via sudoedit -s.
XZ Utils backdoor. Malicious code injected into xz compression library versions 5.6.0 and 5.6.1, enabling SSH authentication bypass on affected systems.
Citrix Bleed: Information disclosure in Citrix NetScaler. Allows session token theft and unauthorized access without credentials.

SSH brute force attacks commonly originate from botnets using credential stuffing. Typical pattern: 5-50 attempts/minute from single IP, targeting root/admin/deploy accounts. Often precedes lateral movement.

Port scanning reconnaissance typically targets common service ports (22, 80, 443, 3306, 5432, 6379, 27017). Nmap SYN scans from external IPs indicate pre-attack probing. Often followed by exploitation within 24-48 hours.

Data exfiltration via SCP/SFTP to external IPs. Attackers stage data in /tmp, compress with tar/gzip, then transfer. Transfers >100MB to non-corporate IPs are high-confidence indicators of exfiltration.
Lateral movement via SSH key reuse. After compromising one host, attackers use stolen SSH keys to pivot to internal servers. Internal-to-internal SSH on non-standard ports is a strong indicator.
Privilege escalation via sudo misconfiguration. Attackers exploit NOPASSWD entries, wildcard injection in sudoers, or known sudo CVEs to gain root access after initial foothold.
Living-off-the-land techniques using standard tools: curl/wget for C2, crontab for persistence, netcat for reverse shells. These bypass signature-based detection by using legitimate binaries.
Leaky Vessels: Container escape vulnerability in runc. Allows attackers to break out of container isolation and access the host filesystem.
Database exfiltration pattern: mysqldump or pg_dump to local file, followed by compression and SCP to external IP. Often occurs during off-hours to avoid detection.
F5 BIG-IP authentication bypass. Remote unauthenticated attacker can execute arbitrary system commands via the management port.

Agent Goal Hijack: Prompt injection or plan manipulation causes the AI agent to pursue attacker-chosen objectives instead of its intended task. Adversaries craft inputs that override system instructions, redirect multi-step plans, or alter the agent's decision-making criteria.

Tool Misuse & Exploitation: An AI agent is tricked into using its tools in harmful or unintended ways. Attackers exploit the agent's ability to call APIs, execute code, or access databases to perform unauthorized actions such as data deletion, resource provisioning, or credential extraction.

Agent Identity & Privilege Abuse: An AI agent operates with overly broad permissions or impersonates privileged identities. Attackers leverage the agent's elevated access to bypass authorization controls, access restricted resources, or escalate privileges across connected systems.

Agentic Supply Chain Compromise: Malicious or vulnerable third-party tools, plugins, or models are integrated into an AI agent's toolchain. Compromised dependencies can exfiltrate data, inject backdoors, or manipulate agent behavior without detection.

Unexpected Code Execution: An AI agent generates and executes code that performs unintended or dangerous operations. Attackers manipulate the agent into producing malicious code through carefully crafted inputs, leading to system compromise, data destruction, or lateral movement.

Memory & Context Poisoning: An attacker corrupts the agent's memory, conversation history, or retrieval-augmented context to influence future decisions. Poisoned context causes the agent to trust malicious data, make flawed decisions, or leak sensitive information from prior interactions.

Insecure Inter-Agent Communication: Messages between collaborating agents lack authentication, encryption, or integrity checks. Attackers intercept or forge inter-agent messages to redirect tasks, inject malicious instructions, or extract sensitive data exchanged between agents.

Cascading Agent Failures: A failure or compromise in one agent propagates through a multi-agent system, causing widespread disruption. Lack of fault isolation means a single poisoned agent can corrupt shared state, trigger infinite loops, or cause denial of service across the entire pipeline.

Human-Agent Trust Exploitation: The agent manipulates users into trusting its outputs or granting additional permissions through social engineering. Attackers use the agent as a proxy to deliver convincing phishing, fabricate authoritative-looking reports, or pressure humans into unsafe approvals.

Rogue Agents: An AI agent deviates from its intended behavior and operates autonomously toward unauthorized goals. This can result from adversarial manipulation, reward hacking, or emergent behavior, leading to unauthorized data access, resource abuse, or actions that contradict operator intent.
